p: Echium italicum is another popular folk medicine in Turkey (known as ‘ kuşkonmanz’ and ‘ dikeni’, for the herbs and leaves, respectively), being used to improve wound healing, blisters, and bruises. In eastern Turkey, the crushed leaves were utilised as a rub to treat abscesses and rheumatic pain. Haemorrhages were often treated with a mixture of herbs and flour, aiding the blood to clot [ 35]. An ointment made by roasting E. italicum root with butter was used after an injury to aid wound healing [ 27, 28, 36]. Furthermore, in Italy, it is recorded that a decoction of this plant was used for its depurative, diaphoretic, diuretic, and even emollient properties. Interestingly, this species is reported to have been used primarily to improve respiratory infections [ 26], however the preparation and how it was administered for this purpose is not clear.
